newsitem.title: REPUBLIC OF IRELAND: PRESS DIGEST - Ireland - November 20.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - Ireland - November 20.

text.p: Following are the highlights of stories reported in the Irish press on Wednesday.

- An inquiry into irregularities in the Department of Justice has baulked at blaming individual civil servants for the "quite inexcusable" failure to implement the government decision to delist a judge from the Special Criminal Court.

- The former Irish prime minister, Albert Rynolds, now facing one million sterling legal costs, is planning to appeal against the decision by a London jury to award him no damages in his libel action against the Sunday Times newspaper.
- One of Ireland's biggest beef farmers had a six-month prison sentence for possessing illegal growth promoters doubled to 12 months when he appealed against the severity of the original sentence.
- An attempt to move the multi-party Northern Ireland talks process beyond decommissioning to substantive negotiations will be made at tonight's Anglo-Irish Conference meeting at Stormont.
- Loyalist politicians have warned that unionist attempts to turn the decommissioning issue into an insurmountable barrier could bring about the collapse of the Stormont talks "within days".
- Four new cases of BSE confirmed by the Department of Agriculture brings the total to 54 so far this year, the highest on record since 1989.
- A major row will explode in parliament on Wednesday over the government's decision to defer questions to the prime minister and the minister for justice on a judicial controversy.
- The British medical insurer BUPA's basic health care scheme will on average be seven percent cheaper for all age groups than the Irish VHI.
- The errors which led to a judicial fiasco that has rocked the government in recent weeks were condemned by an inquiry team as "inexcusable".
- Ireland's retail and export sectors received an electronic boost on Tuesday when Bank of Ireland launched the country's first Internet Shopping Mall. --Dublin Newsroom +353 1 676 9775
